“The ten thousand things are all brought to completion by us. [Many interpreters follow Zhu Xi in translating this, “The ten thousand things are all complete within us.” However, this interpretationonly makes sense if one accepts the metaphysics of the School of the Way. On Zhu Xi’s reading, this chapter “is referring to what the Pattern is fundamentally. . . . There is not a single aspect of the Pattern that is not completely internal to our nature.”]

than to force oneself to act out of sympathetic understanding.” [On “Genuineness,” see the commentary on4A12. “Sympathetic understanding” is defined in the Analects as “not inflicting on others what you do not desire yourself” (15.24). Kongzi’s disciple Zengzi suggests that it is one of the two most important aspects of the Confucian Way (4.15).2 Zhu Xi thinks verses 7A4.2 and 3 describe two different states of ethical development: “If one turns toward oneself and is Genuine, one is already benevolent. But if one is not Genuine,there are still selfish thoughts interfering, and the Pattern is not pure.Hence, in all activities one should force oneself to extend (one’s sympathies)to others. When one is close to the general Pattern, benevolence is not far away.”]

Вот почему благородный муж же-лает обрести его в себе2. Еще Дж. Легг отмечал туманность этого рассуждения. Его главный предмет вы-ражен местоимением чжи 之, в переводе: «то, что», «его», «в нем», «ему». Под ниммогли понимать самого человека либо что-то внешнее по отношению к нему (дао,мудрость, учение, знание). Другое ключевое слово здесь — местоименное наречиецзы 自 «сам», «себя» — тоже интерпретировалось весьма широко, включая его про-тивоположные значения «сознательно» и «само собой», «непроизвольно». Но этунеопределенность Мэнцзы использовал для обобщения, в которое вполне укладыва-ются указанные выше разногласия. Образы безопасного жилища и источника — яв-ные метафоры человечности и сердца, составляющие сознание и сущность человека(см. вводный коммент. к 7.10, а также 3.6). Признак глубины указывает, собственно,на ту же метафору (см., например, его прямую ассоциацию с сердцем в 13.14). ...

只看是否符合道义。”【讲解】孔子认为人的修养的最高境界是“权”，在维护道义的原则下，为实现大的功利目标，要懂得权衡利弊，能屈能伸，不能因小失大。“言必信，行必果”的人，他们会恪守一些做人的准则，固执直率而不知变通。这种人过分机械地遵守原则，能伸不能屈，知进不知退，往往不能进入融通的境界，不具备在政治斗争中权衡利弊的眼光，不懂得丢卒保车或以退求进的策略思想，所以不能独立担当重任。他们会是一个行为没有瑕疵的士兵，却不能成为富于韬略的将军。说话要求诚实，行事要求坚持原则，都是有具体的前提条件的，如果是“必”，就显得机械而片面了。事实上有的时候人们不得不说谎，也不得不中途放弃对某些具体目标的追求，从而保证最终结果的合理性。
“有德行的人，

与义同在，依义而行。”

нотолько там находится, где справедливость1.—————Этот афоризм представляет собой реминисценцию (парафраз) двух известных из-речений Конфуция, из которых первое образует его структурную основу: «В делахпод Небесами благородный муж ничем не дорожит и не пренебрегает, но следуеттому, что справедливо» (Луньюй, 4.10), а второе — среднюю часть: «Им будет, несо-мненно, малый человек, ибо он всегда правдив в словах и решителен в поступках...»(там же, 13.20). У Конфуция одним из существенных признаков «справедливости»и 義 было соответствие моменту и обстоятельствам, означавшее отказ от какой-либоабстрактной преднамеренности*2. Эту ситуативную обусловленность добродетельно-го поведения Мэнцзы также делает одним из основополагающих принципов своегоучения (см. 3.1 и др.). Именно она и могла приводить к нарушению нравственныхнорм, диктовавшемуся более высокими моральными соображениями (см. 7.17, 7.26).

Если ему не вредить, питая его прямотой, то заполняет [все] междуНебом и землей23. Это [такой] порыв, что составляет пару справедливости и пути,без них же истощается24. Он возникает от накопления справедливых [дел], и им,[врасплох] штурмуя его справедливостью, не завладеть25. От поступков, вызы-вающих в сердце недовольство, истощается26. Поэтому я и говорю, что Гаоцзыникогда не имел понятия о справедливости, считая ее чем-то внешним27. [Она]же требует обязательной работы над собой, но без цели [взращивать порыв];нельзя не помнить сердцем, но и нельзя [специально] помогать расти28. Не будемпоходить на сунца. Средь сунцев был один, который, горюя, что всходы его нерастут, их подтянул и, обессиленный, придя домой, сказал домашним: «Ну и ус-тал же [я] сегодня! Я помогал всходам расти». Его сын побежал взглянуть на них,и оказалось, что они завяли29. В Поднебесной мало тех, кто не помогал бы всхо-дам вырасти. Считать это бесполезным и отбрасывать — значит оставлять всхо-ды без прополки. А помогать им вырасти — значит их вытягивать, и [это] дляних будет не только бесполезно, но и гибельно30.

В былые времена Цзыгун спросил Конфуция:«[Вы], учитель, [обрели] премудрость?» Конфуций ответил:Премудрость [обрести] мне не по силам. Но я в учении ненасытен и в наставлениине знаю устали.Цзыгун тогда сказал:Учиться ненасытно — [значит] быть умным, наставлять без устали — [значит]быть человечным; имея [такой] ум и человечность, [вы], учитель, несомненно, [обрели]премудрость.О чем [ты] говоришь, [если] на то, чтобы быть премудрым, не притязал [даже]Конфуций36?!— Мне прежде вот что довелось услышать: у Цзыся, Цзыю и Цзычжана былау каждого какая-то одна часть премудрого человека, а Жань Ню, Минь Цзы иЯнь Юань обладали понемногу всеми37. Осмеливаюсь спросить, к [каким из нихвы] отнесли бы [себя]38?— Оставим пока это39.— А каковы Старший Ровный и И Инь40?— Не одного пути41. Государю, [если тот] был не по нему, [он] не служил; наро-ду, [если тот] был не по нему, не отдавал приказов; при наличии порядка поступал[на службу], при смуте удалялся, [таким] был Старший Ровный42. Служил любомугосударю, повелевал любым народом; и при наличии порядка, и [во время] смутыпоступал [на службу], [таким] был И Инь43. Можно было — [он] служил, а мож-но — брал отставку, можно — медлил [уходить], а можно — проявлял поспеш-ность, [таким] был Конфуций44. Все [трое] были древними премудрыми людьми. Их[путями] я еще не могу идти. Но то, чего желаю, так [это] следовать Конфуцию45.

That is wisdom(zhi 知).”The word zhi 知 can mean knowledge (or to know), wisdom (zhi 智),understanding, realization, and setting one’s heart-mind on something (andhence having aspiration). Of the six occurrences of the word in this passage,the first seems to mean aspiration (see the following quote from theXun Zi), the middle four are commonly taken as “know” or “knowledge”(although the Dingzhou text has all six written as zhi 智). The last onecan be read either as “knowledge” or “wisdom,” but (again given the quotefrom the Xun Zi) it seems better to be taken as wisdom.The Master’s remark reminds us of Socrates’ “knowing one’s own ignoranceis wisdom,” and Lao Zi’s “To know that you don’t know is knowledge/wisdom. To say that you know when you don’t know is an illness” (Lao Zi,chap. 71). While ordinarily people think that the more one learns the moreone knows, interestingly and paradoxically, the more one learns the moreone realizes how much one does not know. Of the six occurrences of the word in this passage, the first seems to mean aspiration (see the following quote from theXun Zi), the middle four are commonly taken as “know” or “knowledge” (although the Dingzhou text has all six written as zhi 智). The last one can be read either as “knowledge” or “wisdom,” but (again given the quote from the Xun Zi) it seems better to be taken as wisdom.The Master’s remark reminds us of Socrates’ “knowing one’s own ignorance is wisdom,” and Lao Zi’s “To know that you don’t know is knowledge/wisdom. To say that you know when you don’t know is an illness” (Lao Zi,chap. 71). While ordinarily people think that the more one learns the more one knows, interestingly and paradoxically, the more one learns the more one realizes how much one does not know. But there is more in Confucius’ teaching than simply knowing one’s ignorance—it is also an attitude toward life, as is illustrated in a fuller account of the story in the Xun Zi:Zilu dressed in fancy clothes when he came to see Confucius. Confucius said, “You [Zilu], what is the reason for the fanciness?Early on, when the Yangtze emerges from Mount Min, at its origin its flow is barely enough to overflow a goblet. But when it reaches the crossing point, then without tying together boats and avoiding the winds, you would not be able to cross it. Is this not simply because of the vast amount of water flowing own? Now your clothes are fancy and your countenance is puffed up. Who in the world would be willing to remonstrate with you like this?”

of the Three Treasures would save them from their sad plight. As they heard that the Sixteen-foot Buddha of Daian-ji XXX would respond to the people's prayers, they sent a man to visit the temple and have scriptures recited. They made an appeal to the monks, saying, "When we are led to court, please open the southern gate of the temple so that we may pay homage to the Buddha. Also we beg you to ring the bell when we are taken to court so that the sound of the bell may follow us." According to their wishes, the monks rang the bell, recited scriptures, and opened the gate so that the people might worship. The latter were sent to court by the messengers and confined in a guardroom. Just then a prince was born, and the emperor granted a general amnesty to criminals and did not punish them. Instead, he gave alms to the people, and their happiness and joy could not bemeasured. We learn that this is due to the influence of the Sixteen-foot Buddha and the merit of reciting scriptures.

[Zhu Xi explains this difficult passageas follows: “Gaozi said that if there is something that onedoes not understand in doctrines, then one should set thedoctrine aside and need not examine and search for thePattern in one’s heart. If one is not at peace in one’s heart,then one should regulate one’s {38} heart with force andneed not further seek for help from the qi. This is the wayin which he firmly maintained his heart and quicklybecame unperturbed. Having recited Gaozi’s doctrines,Mengzi passes judgment on them: When Gaozi says thatwhat you do not get from your heart you should not seekfor in the qi, this is being concerned about the root andrelaxed about the branches—that is acceptable. When hesays that what you do not get from doctrines you shouldnot seek from the heart, then he is already lost due toexternal things, and so has left behind what is internal.This is necessarily unacceptable.”David S. Nivison offered an alternative interpretation,based on a parallel between this passage and Zhuangzi’sfictional dialogue between “Kongzi” and “Yan Hui”:Gaozi recommends that we completely commit ourselvesto following correct ethical doctrines, forcing our heartand our qi to follow what they dictate. In contrast, Mengzirecommends that we not only follow ethical doctrines butseek further to find the basis for these doctrines in thereactions of our heart (2A6, 6A10), which will then guideour qi. Finally, Zhuangzi recommends that we ultimatelyeschew doctrines, empty our hearts, and follow thepromptings of the qi, which unites us with other things.5]

Withoutthis qi, then even if one’s actions do not necessarilydiverge from the Way and righteousness, nonetheless one’sbody will not be filled with qi, so that one cannot avoiddoubts and fears, and one will be unable to be effective.”][2.15] It is produced by accumulated righteousness. It cannotbe obtained by a seizure of righteousness. If some of one’sactions leave one’s heart unsatisfied, it will starve.Consequently, I say that Gaozi never understoodrighteousness, because he regarded it as external. [Zhu Xiexplains, “This means that, although qi can harmonizewith the Way and righteousness, the beginning ofnurturing it is to have every action accord withrighteousness. If one examines oneself and is constantly{40} upright, one will be ashamed of nothing, and this qiwill naturally be produced from within. One cannot doonly a single action that accidentally accords withrighteousness and then get it by a ‘seizure’ of what isexternal. ‘If some of one’s actions leave one’s heartunsatisfied, it will starve’ means that as soon as what onedoes is not in accord with righteousness and one examinesoneself and is not upright, then there will be aninadequacy in one’s heart, and one’s body will not befilled. This being the case, how could righteousness beexternal? Gaozi did not understand the Pattern of this, sohe said, ‘Benevolence is internal,’ ‘righteousness isexternal’ (6A4–5), and because he did not regardbecoming righteous as a task, he was necessarily unable toaccumulate righteousness in order to produce thefloodlike qi. The earlier verse, ‘What you do not get fromdoctrines, do not seek for in your heart’ (2A2.9a), isprecisely the meaning of treating righteousness asexternal.”]

Do not be like the man from Song. Among the peopleof the state of Song there was a farmer who, concerned lest hissprouts not grow, pulled on them. Obliviously, he returnedhome and said to his family, ‘Today I am worn out. I helpedthe sprouts to grow.’ His son rushed out and looked at them.The sprouts were withered. [The people of the state of Songwere the butt of many jokes because of their supposedstupidity. We might say that the farmer from Song issomeone who “act[ed] out benevolence andrighteousness,” rather than “acting out of benevolence andrighteousness” (4B19.2). Zhu Xi comments, “Those whonurture their qi must take accumulating righteousness astheir task but not anticipate its effectiveness. If theyhappen to fail to be filled (with floodlike qi), they shouldsimply not forget what they are in service to, and may notdo anything to ‘help’ it grow. This is the process foraccumulating righteousness [2.16b] and nurturing the qi.”]Those in the world who do not ‘help’ the sprouts to grow arefew. Those who abandon them, thinking it will not help, arethose who do not weed their sprouts. Those who ‘help’ themgrow are those who pull on the sprouts. Not only does this nothelp, but it even harms them.” [Zhu Xi comments, “Thosewho abandon them and do not weed forget what they areworking for. Those who pull on them and ‘help’ them togrow assume they have it, and when they do not get it,they act recklessly. If one does not weed, then one willonly fail to nurture it, but if one pulls on it, then one will,on the contrary, harm it. If one avoids these two things,then one’s qi will be nurtured and will not be injured. Iflike Gaozi one is unable to {41} accumulate righteousnessbut desires to force one’s heart to be regulated, then onewill be unable to avoid the twin faults of assuming andassisting. Not only will he not be good at cultivating the‘floodlike,’ but he will even harm it.”Iris Murdoch makes a similar point: “Self-knowledge willlead us to avoid occasions of temptation rather than torely on naked strength to overcome them. We must notarrogate to ourselves actions which belong to those whosespiritual vision is higher or other than ours. From thisattempt, only disaster will come.” In short, “One mustperform the lower act which one can manage and sustain:not the higher act that one bungles.”6]

“請問,老師擅長哪一方面?”孟子説:“我説話得體,還善於培養我的浩然之氣。”“請問,什麽叫作‘浩然之氣’呢?”孟子説:“很難講清楚。它作爲一種氣呀,最浩大,最堅强。用正直去培養它,讓它没有損害,就會充沛洋溢在天地之間。這種氣呀,必須配合輔助道和義;而缺乏它,道和義就没有力量了。這種氣是由正義彙聚而産生的,不是由正義繼承並取代它而産生的。只要做一次問心有愧的事,它就疲軟了。所以我説,告子是不懂義的,因爲他把它看做心外之物。〔其實義是心内固有的。〕一定要慎重對待它,卻不刻意扶持它;時刻惦記它,卻不刻意助它成長———不要學那個宋國人的樣。宋國有一個擔心禾苗生長不快而去把它拔高的人,傻乎乎地回到家中,對家人説:‘今天累壞了! 我幫助禾苗生長了!’他兒子趕快跑去一看,禾苗都枯槁了。其實天下不幫助禾苗生長的人是很少的。認爲〔鋤草〕没好處而放棄不幹的,就是種莊稼不鋤草的懶漢;‘幫助’它生長的,就是拔苗的人———非但没有好處,反而傷害了它。”【注釋】①知言:説話得體。參見《論語新注新譯》20.3《考證》(二)。②無害:没有損害,没有危害。詳見本節《考證》(一)。 ③配義與94 孟子新注新譯(第二版)道:配合輔助義和道。配,配合。詳見本節《考證》(二)。 ④ 慊(qiè):同“愜”,滿足,暢快。 ⑤外之:把它看做外在的。 ⑥必有事焉而勿正:必有事焉,一定要慎重對待它。正,使正,扶正它。詳見本節《考證》(三)。 ⑦心勿忘:焦循《孟子正義》説:“‘忘’通‘妄’,即《易》‘無妄’之‘妄’。”不確。詳見本節《考證》(四)。 ⑧閔其苗之不長而揠(yà)之:閔,今作“憫”,憂慮。揠,拔。 ⑨芒芒然:茫然若失的樣子,傻乎乎的樣子。詳見本節《考證》(五)。 ⑩其人:其家人。􀃊􀁉􀁓病:疲倦。 􀃊􀁉􀁔苗則槁矣:這句“則”字所連接的兩項中,第二件事情的出現,不是第一件事情的施事者所預料的。類似者如:“使子路反見之,至則行矣。” 􀃊􀁉􀁕耘:又作“芸”,除草。

There is a painted image of Amida 阿彌陀 in the Hata-dera 八多寺 in Ishikawa district, Kawachi province 河内國石川郡. Villagers say that a wise woman once lived in this neighborhood, but her name is unknown. On the day her husband was dying, she vowed to make an image of Amida, but many years passed and the vow was not fulfilled because of her poverty. One autumn she gleaned in the rice fields, commissioned a painter, and made offerings to the dead for the first time, weeping in her sorrow. In sympathy, the painter joined in her devotion and completed a beautiful painting. After a ceremonial feastS it was consecrated in the golden hall of the temple, and she paid constant homage to it. A thief later set fire to the hall, and it was destroyed. Only the Buddha image survived the fire, suffering no damage. Wasn't it a miraculous work of Buddha to help the woman? The note says: How good a wife she was in holding a memorial rite for her husband! Eventually she held it in the autumn. We know indeed how devoted she was. Even blazing flames cannot consume the holy image. Heaven's help is beyond our comprehension.

Hardly a week passed before a gale hit, and the robes were whisked south on the back of a deer to the original owners' garden; the deer then disappeared in the heavens. The merchant who had bought them, hearing that they were stolen goods, did not ask for them back but kept quiet.

如果這樣，那麼先生動心不動心呢？”孟子說：“不動心。我四十歲就不動心了。”公孫丑說：“要是這樣，那麼先生就遠遠超過孟賁了。”孟子說：“這并不難。告子在我之前就做到了不動心。”公孫丑說：“要做到不動心有方法嗎？”孟子說：“有。北宫黝培養自己的勇氣，肌肤被刺而不退縮，眼睛被刺而絕不避開；他認爲即便是一根毫毛被傷害，也如同在衆目睽睽之下遭受鞭笞一般羞辱；他不能忍受地位低賤的人的摧折，也不能忍受大國君王的摧折；他看待刺殺大國君王，就如同刺殺一名穿粗布衣服的貧賤之人；他對諸侯全無敬畏之心，對方如果惡語相向，他一定予以回擊。孟施舍培養勇氣的方法，用他的話說：‘看待不能戰勝的對手，跟足以戰勝的對手是一樣的；假如充分估量對手的强弱然後才決定進退，先把能否獲勝都算計清楚然後才與對方交手，那麼這是畏懼大軍的人。我孟施舍哪能做到一定獲勝啊？我能做到沒有畏懼罷了。’孟施舍像曾子，北宫黝像子夏。這兩位先生的勇敢，我不知誰更强一些，不過，孟施舍所奉行的主張簡易可行。從前曾子對子襄說：‘您崇尚勇敢嗎？我曾經從我的老師那兒聽說過什麼是大勇：反躬自問，是自己違背道義，那麼即使對方只是穿着粗麻做的寬大衣服的地位低賤的人，我也不會讓對方恐懼不安；如果反躬自問，自己站在道義一方，那麼即使面對千軍萬馬，我也會冲上去了。’孟施舍保守勇氣的方法，又不如曾子所奉行的主張簡易可行。”

was not as good as Zengzi’s preserving whatis crucial.” [As A. C. Graham explains, in Mengzi’s era, qi“is like such words in other cultures as Greek pneuma‘wind, air, breath.’ It is the energetic fluid which vitalisesthe body, in particular as the breath, and which circulates outside us as the air.” Later, this concept is “adapted to cosmology as the universal fluid … out of which all things condense and into which they dissolve.”3 (This late sense is how thinkers like Zhu Xi understood it.) Qi is thus the physical medium through which one’s emotions and personal character are manifested. So to “preserve one’s qi” is to control one’s emotions. Meng Shishe was similarto Zengzi in that both focused on something inside themselves, as opposed to Bogong You and Zixia, who focused on something external to themselves. However, as Zhu Xi explains, “what Meng Shishe preserved was just the qi of one’s self. This is not as good as Zengzi’s examining himself and following the Pattern (of the Way).He preserved what is especially important. Mengzi’s unperturbed heart has its source in this.”4]

Nowadays, it is fashionable for scholars who study the Outer Writings to slander Buddhist teachings, and for those who read the Inner Scriptures to neglect the Outer Writings. They are foolish and deceive themselves, ignoring the consequences of good and evil deeds. But the wise, who are well versed in both the Inner and Outer traditions, stand in awe and believe in the law of karmic causation. There are many examples of piety in the imperial line. For instance, it is said that there was an emperor who climbed a hill to survey his domain, had compassion for the people, and thereafter contented himself with a palace that had a leaky roof. Again, there was a prince who was innately prudent and foresighted, able to listen to ten men addressing him at the same time without missing a single word. Some men defraud temples and are reborn as calves to toil and repay the debts of their former lives; some speak ill of Buddhist teachings and monks and meet with calamity in this present life; some seek the path [of Buddha] by leading a disciplined life of practice and are rewarded in thislife; some practice good with a profound faith and are blissful. Good and evil deeds cause karmic retribution as a figure causes its shadow, and suffering and pleasure follow such deeds as an echofollows a sound in the valley. Those who witness such experiences marvel at them and forget they are real happenings in the world. The penitent withdraws to hide himself, for he bums with shame at once. Were the fact of karmic retribution not known, how could we rectify wickedness and establish righteousness? And how would it bepossible to make men mend their wicked minds and practice the pathof virtue without demonstrating the law of karmic causation? In China, the MyOOhoki (Record of Invisible Work of Karmic Retribution) was compiled, and, during the great T'ang dynasty, the Hannya kenki (A Collection of Miraculous Stories Concerning theKongo hannya-kyo) was written. Since we respect the documents of foreign lands, should we not also believe, and stand in awe of the miraculous events in our own land? Having witnessed these events myself, I cannot remain idle. After long meditation on this, I now break my silence. I have recorded the limited information that has come tome in these three volumes called the Nihonkoku genpo zen'aku ryOOiki, for future generations. However, I am not gifted with either wisdom or lucidity. Learning acquired in a narrow well loses its way when out in the open. My work resembles that of a poor craftsman working on the carving of a master. I am afraid that I will cut my hand and suffer from the injury

I am afraid that I will cut my hand and suffer from the injury long afterward. My work is comparable to a rough pebble beside the K'un-Iun Mountains. Its source in the oral tradition is so indistinct that I am afraid of omitting much. Only the desire to do good has moved me to try, in spite of the fear that this might turn out to be a presumptuous work by an incompetent author. I hope that learned men in future generations will not laugh at my efforts, and I pray thatthose who happen upon this collection of miraculous stories will put aside evil, live in righteousness, and, without causing evil, practice good.

【〖讀後感〗這段文字討論養勇的問題。公孫丑提問的話題是，當一個人得到了實現理想的機會，能否毫無顧慮、勇往直前地去做呢？公孫丑用了“動心”的說法，人在生活中遇到各種突發事件，都會在內心掀起波浪。這種擾動不安的精神狀態，可能包含了種種複雜的情緒。從本章孟子談“養氣”而言，動心是指內心存在疑懼；由本章孟子論“知言”而言，則動心指內心存在惶惑。因此，孟子說“我四十不動心”，正如孔子言“四十而不惑”，都是說一個人到了四十歲，已經明確地樹立了人生的信念，確立了自己的德行，便不會再有疑懼或惶惑。 Реплика Мэнцзы состоит из антитезы двух развернутых метафор и вывода, разъяс-няющего уже прямо, без тропов, их значение. В основе здесь та мысль, что слава че-ловека органически связана с проявлением им своей природы, которая заключаетсяво врожденной доброте (см. вводн. коммент. к 3.2). Источник, дотекающий до мо-рей — границ ойкумены — подразумевает человеческую природу и ее всеохваты-вающую актуализацию (ср. 3.6), а скопление дождевой воды — тип действий, обу-словленный не этим началом, а внешними обстоятельствами. Те же образы соответ-ственно ассоциируются со славой, вечной и эфемерной. «[Естественное] состояние»цин 情 указывает именно на такую существенную актуализацию. 說話詆毁禮義，叫做自己糟蹋自己；自己認爲自己沒有能力做到始終不離開仁道、遵循道義，叫做自己抛棄自己。仁是人安適的居所；義是人正確的道路。把安適的住宅空置起來不去居住，舍棄正確的道路不去行走，可悲啊！〖解說〗漢語中的“自”用法比較特别，放在動詞前面，可以表示自己發出某個行爲動作，而這個行爲動作施及的對象正是自己。如自殺，意思是自己發出“殺”的動作，“殺”的對象則是自己；“自殘”意思是自己傷害自己，“自虐”是自己虐待自己，“自焚”是自己燒死自己。孟子言“自暴自棄”，本來包含兩個方面，一是自暴，相當於說自殘自虐；二是自棄，自己認爲自己不行，沒有能力去行合乎人心人性的仁義之道。自暴者根本不分是非，一副我是流氓我怕誰的姿態，不僅不認同仁義之道，反而把爲非作歹、爲害世人當作自己的權力和榮耀，最終必將成爲百姓的公敵，招致天怒人怨，屬於自作孽不可活的一類。自棄者明白公義和正道，却以種種借口選擇邪路。自暴者任性，自棄者對自己不負責任，都是由於貪欲和自私。後來的成語“自暴自棄”只保留了自棄的含義，大概是緣於孟子對自暴者的極端不屑吧？《孟子·盡心上》：“居惡（wū，哪裏）在？仁是也；路惡在？義是也。居仁由義，大人之事備矣。”君子所追求的，是仁義；孟子解說仁義時，针對不同的對象會有不同的側重，比如對齊國的王子墊，他說：“殺一無罪，非仁也，非其有而取之，非義也。”對於擁有權力的人，不濫殺無辜，不巧取豪奪，也就算做到了仁義。孟子終生都在試圖給君主灌輸仁愛之心和道義情懷，努力爲社會建立一種普世價值。一個占據一定權力資源的人，不能以仁義之道爲己任，這是自棄；因他不能以仁愛之心對待世人，却能利用手裏的權力破壞社會的公平正義，曠之舍之的結果是被民衆抛棄，是自取滅亡。所以孟子嘆息道：“哀哉！”哀是悲痛傷心，也是憐憫同情。

如同湍急的水流，朝東方排水，水就向東流，朝西方排水，水就向西流。人性沒有善和不善的分别，就如同水在向東流和向西流方面沒有分别。”孟子說：“水確實在向東流和向西流方面沒有分别，可是在向上流和向下流方面也沒有分别嗎？人性向善，就好像水往低處流。人性本沒有不善的，水也沒有不往低處流的。對於水來說，用力拍擊它，使它飞溅起來，能使它越過额頭；把水勢阻住使之倒流，可以使它流到山上。這些難道是水的本性嘛？是擊打和阻攔的行爲造成的勢力使得它這樣啊。對於人來說，可以使他爲不善，其性質也正像水受到擊打和阻攔而改變了向下流的本性。”

這些都是打洞翻牆一類的行徑。”〖解說〗孟子認爲，“有所不忍”發自人的本心本性，只是在後天的成長過程中，有的人把這樣的本心本性丢失了，有的人則讓各種骯髒黑暗的東西蒙蔽了心性，於是這些人越來越殘忍暴虐，做出各種醜陋的令人髪指的事情。孟子呼吁人們，把與生俱來的“有所不忍”之心推而廣之，用不忍之心對待與自己密切相關的人和事物，從而達到仁的境界。孟子的可貴之處在於，他借助於人們具體生動的日常經驗和感受，把抽象的道德範疇闡述得相當直觀，而且富有穿透人心的力量。比如仁、義，要定義清楚這兩個概念的內涵和外延，實在不是一件容易的事情。孟子用擴充“不忍”之心和“不爲”之念來解說，簡明扼要，而讀者自可會意其豐富的言外之意。孟子推闡仁義之用，也同樣是“即其所居之位，樂以日用之常”（朱熹語）。不想害人、不肯偷竊、不願被别人輕賤，這些都是普通人的平常心。如果能把這樣的平常心擴充開去，那麼也便稱得上仁義之人了。對於士人而言，還有更高的要求。孟子曾經說：“不仁者可與言哉？”（《孟子·離婁上》）對於毫無仁愛之心、根本不可能實行仁政的君主，還要極力迎合進言，甚至說假話，說違心的話，無非是要趨炎附勢，求得賞識以獲取利益。孟子又說：“齊人無以仁義與王言者，豈以仁義爲不美也？其心曰‘是何足與言仁義也’云爾，則不敬莫大乎是。”不肯與君王談論仁義，是擔心觸怒君王，影響自己的前程。對於士人這類爲攀附權勢、捞取利益而畏首畏尾、蠅營狗苟的做法，孟子怒斥之爲“打洞翻牆一類的行徑”。言，還是不言，體現的是義；從更深一層分析，表現的是當事人的仁。只是，在君主集權的體制下，“未可以言而言”與“可以言而不言”，這其閒的區别和和選擇，也是很不容易把握的啊！“未可以言而言”，在某種意義上是主動放棄不說假話的權利；“可以言而不言”，則是主動放棄說真話的權利，可以說已經完全喪失了士人應有的道義感。

After some loyal subjects burned the temple and threw away Buddha images and some built temples to spread the Buddhist teaching, ex-Emperor Shōhō-ōjin-shōmu made a huge image of the Buddha for the first time. He established the eternal Buddhist tradition in this country, shaved his head, and wore a surplice. He was ordained and practiced good, ruling the people with justice. His compassion was extended to animals and plants, while his virtue was incomparable in history. On the throne he attained unity, had excellent fortune,and appeased all spirits, taking his stand on the three components of the universe. Owing to this fortune and virtue, even insects flying in the sky brought grasses to thatch a temple, while ants running on the ground gathered golden sands to build a pagoda. Buddhist banners were raised high with their fringes flying in all directions. The boat of Buddhism floated lightly on the water, and the shadow of the sails seemed to send wind into the sky. Flowers of good omen opened in rivalry here and there, and karmic retribution of good and evil was revealed in lights and shadows. This is why he was named ex-Emperor Shōhō-ōjin-shōmu, meaning Excellent-treasure-truth-corresponding-sacred-power.

The male crow flewhere and there to bring food for his mate who sheltered the chicks. Once when he left the nest for food, another crow flew into the nest and began to flirt. Attracted by the newcomer, the female crow flew high up into the sky toward the north, abandoning her chicks in the nest. When the male crow came back with food in his mouth and could not find his wife, he watched over the chicks affectionately and did not look for food for many days. The governor noticed this and had someone climb the tree in order to see the nest. The crow and the chicks were dead. Realizing the female crow's adultery, the governor was overcome with pity and his mind was filled with mercy. He renounced the world, leaving his home, family, and rank, and followed the Most Venerable Gyōgi XXX to practice good and seek the path. He was named Shingon. His wife was also of the Chinu no agatanushi. After her husband left her, she remained faithful to him without bitterness. When her dear son contracted a fatal disease and was dying, he said to her, "It will prolong my life if I drink my mother's milk." The mother gave her breast to her son as he had asked. Sucking the breast, he lamented, saying, "I am abandoning the sweet milk of my mother and dying!" and breathed his last. Sorrowing for her deceased son, she renounced

Kusakabe no Matoji 日下部眞⿱[刀目]. In the reign of Emperor ShOmu he was appointed a frontier soldier at Tsukushi XXX by Chomo XXX (his name is unknown) and had to spend three years there. His mother accompanied him and lived with him, while his wife stayed behind to take care of the house. Omaro, out of love for his wife who had been left behind, thought up the wicked idea of killing his mother and returning home to his wife, claiming exemption from duty on the pretext of mourning. As his mother's mind was set on doing good, he said to her, "There will be a great meeting for a week's lecture on the Hoke-kyo XXXin the eastern mountain. Shall we go to hear the teaching?" His mother, deceived, was eager to go, and, devoutly purifying herself in a hot bath, accompanied her son to the mountain. Then he looked at her fiercely, as though with the eyes of a bull, and said, "You, kneel down on the ground!" Gazing at his face, she said, "Why are you talking like that? Are you possessed by a fiend?" The son, however, drew a sword to kill her. Kneeling down in front of her son, she said to him, "We plant a tree in order to get its fruit and to take shelter in its shade. We bring up children in order to get their help and to depend on them. What on earth has driven you so crazy! I feel as though the tree I have been depending on has suddenly ceased to protect me from the rain." He would not listen to her, so she sorrowfully took off her clothes, put them in three piles, knelt down, and told him her last wish: "Will you wrap up these clothes for me? One pile goes to you, my eldest son, one to my second son, and one to my third son." When the wicked son stepped forward to cut off his mother's head, the earth opened to swallow him. Kusakabe no Matoji 日下部眞⿱[刀目]. In the reign of Emperor ShOmu he was appointed a frontier soldier at Tsukushi XXX by Chomo XXX (his name is unknown) and had to spend three years there. His mother accompanied him and lived with him, while his wife stayed behind to take care of the house. Omaro, out of love for his wife who had been left behind, thought up the wicked idea of killing his mother and returning home to his wife, claiming exemption from duty on the pretext of mourning. As his mother's mind was set on doing good, he said to her, "There will be a great meeting for a week's lecture on the Hoke-kyo XXXin the eastern mountain. Shall we go to hear the teaching?" His mother, deceived, was eager to go, and, devoutly purifying herself in a hot bath, accompanied her son to the mountain. Then he looked at her fiercely, as though with the eyes of a bull, and said, "You, kneel down on the ground!" Gazing at his face, she said, "Why are you talking like that? Are you possessed by a fiend?" The son, however, drew a sword to kill her. Kneeling down in front of her son, she said to him, "We plant a tree in order to get its fruit and to take shelter in its shade. We bring up children in order to get their help and to depend on them. What on earth has driven you so crazy! I feel as though the tree I have been depending on has suddenly ceased to protect me from the rain." He would not listen to her, so she sorrowfully took off her clothes, put them in three piles, knelt down, and told him her last wish: "Will you wrap up these clothes for me? One pile goes to you, my eldest son, one to my second son, and one to my third son." When the wicked son stepped forward to cut off his mother's head, the earth opened to swallow him. At that moment his mother grabbed her falling son by the hair and appealed to Heaven, wailing, "My child is possessed by some spirit and driven to such an evil deed. He is out of his mind. I beseech you to forgive his sin." In spite of all her efforts to pull him up by the hair, he fell down. The merciful motherbrought his hair back home to hold funeral rites and put it in a boxin front of a Buddha image, asking monks to chant scriptures.1OHow great was the mother's compassion! So much that she lovedan evil son and practiced good on his behalf. Indeed, we know thatan unfllial sin is punished immediately and that an evil deed nevergoes without a penalty.

Then he looked at her fiercely, as though with the eyes of a bull, and said, "You, kneel down on the ground!" Gazing at his face, she said, "Why are you talking like that? Are you possessed by a fiend?" The son, however, drew a sword to kill her. Kneeling down in front of her son, she said to him, "We plant a tree in order to get its fruit and to take shelter in its shade. We bring up children in order to get their help and to depend on them. What on earth has driven you so crazy! I feel as though the tree I have been depending on has suddenly ceased to protect me from the rain." He would not listen to her, so she sorrowfully took off her clothes, put them in three piles, knelt down, and told him her last wish: "Will you wrap up these clothes for me? One pile goes to you, my eldest son, one to my second son, and one to my third son." When the wicked son stepped forward to cut off his mother's head, the earth opened to swallow him. At that moment his mother grabbed her falling son by the hair and appealed to Heaven, wailing, "My child is possessed by some spirit and driven to such an evil deed. He is out of his mind. I beseech you to forgive his sin." In spite of all her efforts to pull him up by the hair, he fell down. The merciful mother brought his hair back home to hold funeral rites and put it in a box in front of a Buddha image, asking monks to chant scriptures. How great was the mother's compassion! So much that she loved an evil son and practiced good on his behalf. Indeed, we know that an unfllial sin is punished immediately and that an evil deed never goes without a penalty.

In the state of Chu, a man was caught in a heavywind while traveling by boat, when huge waves arose hejumped into the water on his own. It was not that he did notwant to survive, the problem was that he forgot how tosurvive for fear that he might lose his life. Hence, men'sdesires and lust are somewhat the same as the aforementionedcase. In the state of Qi, there was a case of a man stealinggold. He arrived at the market at a busy time, picked up thegold and left. After he was caught, people asked him, "Howdare you steal gold at the busy time?" He replied, "I did notsee anybody here, I only paid attention to the gold. " He didnot know what he was doing because he was overlyconcentrated on his goal. Hence, sages examine the changesof movement and stillness in order to be moderate inaccepting and giving, and they reconcile their love and hate tosmooth their joy and anger. Since the changes of movement- and stillness are recognized, they will not get into trouble; since they are moderate m accepting and giving, they will notcommit any sins; since love and hate are reconciled, they willbe freed from sadness; and since joy and anger are smoothed,they will not trigger any bitterness. 因此礼乐从来都不是固定不变的。所以圣人制定礼乐，但是不受礼乐限制；治理国家虽然有常规，但必须以对人民有利为根本原则；政令教化虽然有规范，但必须以能切令卷十三汜论761实可行为最好；只要对人民有利，就不一定要效法古制；只要切合实际情况，就不一定要遵循旧法。夏朝、商朝到了末世，桀和纣没有改变古制还是灭亡了；夏、商、周刚兴起的时候，夏禹、商汤、周武王不因袭旧法却兴旺发达起来。所以圣人的法度随着时势的变化而变化，礼节随着风俗习惯的不同而改变，衣服器具各各便利实用，法令制度各各适合时宜。所以改变古制无可非议，因循世俗不值得赞美。

贪得财物不顾羞耻，想再用神农氏那种方法来治理，就必定乱套了。伯成子高拒绝封为诸侯，情愿隐居种田，天下人都赞美他品行高洁；如今的人拒绝做官，就被乡下人憔门不上眼，哪能再同古代一样呢！古代的兵器，只有弓和剑罢了，木矛没有铁刃，长戟没有锋尖。近代的兵器，冲车做得又高又大用来攻城，壕沟和帐幕用来防守，连发的机弩用来射杀，装有尖刀的战车用来打斗。古代攻克敌国，不杀小孩，不捉老人，那时认为是讲人道，今天再这么做便被人嘲笑。古人引以为光荣的事情，今人认为是丢人的；古代用来治理好天下的办法，今天会搞乱天下。神农、伏羲不实行赏罚老百姓不干坏事，可是今天执政的人不能再废除法令来治理百姓；虞舜执干戚而舞使有苗族归顺，可是今天征伐的人不能再丢开武器去制止暴乱。由此看来，制定法律制度，是用来反映人民的习俗的，应该宽严适度；器械用具，必须随着时代的变化而变化，制作应该恰当适用。

如果盲从古法，不过是长辈立法，晚辈照搬罢了。如果懂得法治产生的根由，那么就能适应时世而变法；如果不懂得法治产生的根源，即使因袭古法旧制，到头来还是会乱套。现在的法典已经随着时代变化，礼仪巳经随着风俗改变，而那些做学问的人还是因袭死守前人的老套，以为离了这些老古董便不能治国平天下，这如同拿上方形的裨头硬朝圆形的裨眼里塞，想要能够相合而又牢固，那就难了。如今的儒家、墨家之徒，称颂三代、周文王周武王的古法，可自己又不实行，这等于宣扬行不通的东西；非议眼前的现实可是又不去改造，这等千听任自己反对的东西存在下去。称颂自己认为正确的，做的却是自己认为错误的，因此整天伤透脑筋却对治国没好处，劳损身体耗尽智力却对君王没帮助。现在那些画工总爱画鬼怪而讨厌画狗马，啥道理呢？鬼怪不在世上出现，而狗马人们天天见到，画鬼容易画狗马难啊！挽救危局，治理乱世，没有聪明才智办不到；但是称颂老古董，即使是笨蛋，智能也绰绰有余。所以无用的法规，圣王不采用；不符实际的话，明君不听取。

说一不二，从不宽赦。子阳的家臣中有个人折断了一只弓，他畏罪害怕被杀，就趁街市上人们追杀疯狗造成的动乱，杀死子阳。这就是刚毅猛烈造成的悲剧。如今那些不懂得宽猛相济这个道理的人，他们看到柔弱怯懦便会被人欺凌，就追求刚毅猛烈；看到刚毅猛烈招致灭亡，就追求柔弱怯懦。这种人心中没有根本作主心骨，让所见所闻的外界事物来搅乱自己的思想，所以一辈子没有固定的方向。比如不懂音律的人唱歌，唱低音时沉闷而不婉转悠扬，唱高音时干涩而不圆润。说到韩娥、秦青、薛谈、侯同、曼声这些名歌手，不论是无伴奏的随意哼吟，还是合乐的演唱，都是内心积聚着愤激的感情，这种感情充满胸中，通过音乐表露出来，因此没有不合音律而且不和谐动心的。这是为什么呢？因为他们心里有根本主宰着来确定音调的高低变化，不受外界事物的干扰，自成法度。现在那盲人走在路上，别人叫他往左走他就往左走，叫他朝右走他就朝右走；碰上君子给他指引到平坦安全的路上，遇到小人害他陷进深沟。为什么呢？因为他眼睛看不见外物。所以魏国换着用楼翟、吴起守西河而失去了西河，齐涽王专用淖齿一人而被淖齿杀死在东庙，都是由于没有权术驾驭臣属；周文王同时任用姜太公吕望和召公爽而治理好天下，楚庄王专用孙叔敖一人而称霸诸侯，都是由千有权术驾驭臣属。

在这种时候，忠谏的人被认为不吉利，讲仁义的人被当成狂人。到了我们汉朝高帝起兵时，保存要灭亡的，延续绝嗣的，高举义旗，心怀愤激之情，亲自手持兵器，为百姓向皇天请命。在这时，天下英雄豪杰，在荒原草野风餐露宿，冲杀时冒着利箭滚石，撤退时落进溪谷，不顾百次死亡的危险，才得到一次生存机会，这样来争夺天下的统治权，奋发勇武精神，激励忠诚之心，来决定一时的命运。在这样的时世，穿上宽衣系着博带谈论儒学墨学的人，被看成无才之辈。等到暴秦巳被推翻，战乱已经平息，天下巳经安定，我们高帝继承周文王的事业，建立了周武王那样的功勋，登上了天子宝座，当年的竹皮帽被称为“刘氏冠”而风行天下，聚集邹、鲁的儒墨学者，贯彻先圣的遗教，树立起天子之旗，乘坐天子的大车，造出九耀旌旗，撞击大钟，敲打响鼓，演奏《咸池》古乐，举着干戚起舞。在这样的形势之下，有谁要提倡武力便会被怀疑居心匝测。一时之间，主张文德和崇尚武功两种人交换着高低胜负地位，这是由于时世的需要所造成的。现在尚武的人非议崇文的人，崇文的人非议尚武的人，崇文尚武互相非议，他们不懂得文武各适用千不同的时世。这些人只看到一个小角落、一根手指头，而不知道世界有多么广大。所以说朝东望，看不见西墙；朝南看，见不到北方；只有不偏向任何一方，才能无所不知，无所不晓。

所以夏桀被关在南巢，还不能够否定他自己的所作所为，反而后悔没有把汤杀死在夏台；殷纣王被围困在宣室，还不知道反省自己的罪过，反而后悔没有把周文王杀死在茨里。假如夏桀、殷纣王这两个君王处在势力强大的时候，能够实行仁义之道，商汤、周武王纠正罪过都来不及，还能有什么图谋呢！如果上乱日月星辰的光辉，下失万民之心，即令没有商汤、周武王，谁个不能夺走天下呢？现在不检查自己身上的罪恶，却反而防范别人，须知天下不是只有一个商汤和一个周武王，杀掉一个商汤、周武王，一定还有接踵而起的人。再说商汤、周武王之所以能处在弱小的地位最后称王，是因为他们手中有道义；夏桀、殷纣王之所以处在强大的地位终千被夺走天下，是因为他们无道。如果现在有人不采用前人称王天下的经验，反而增加自身导致被剥夺的行为，这是走向灭亡的道路呢。周武王消灭了殷王朝以后，想在太行山上修建宫殿。周公说：＂这不可以的！那太行山区，是闭塞险阻的地方。如果我们能够以德政治理天下，那么，天下各地前来朝拜进贡的使者走迂回曲折的路，不利千他们前来；如果我们实行暴政，那么天下讨伐我们的正义之师难以顺利完成他们的光荣使命。”这就是周朝延续三十六代而不被人夺走江山的原因，周公可称得上能够正确对待满盈的了。

贵和贱不讲次序，军人的甲胄长了蚔乱，燕子家雀在军营里安家，战争还无休无止，在这种局势之下才想着实行儒家的恭谨俭朴的礼节，那一定被消灭、受压抑而不能兴盛。假如天下安宁，政教平和，百姓恭顺和睦，君臣关系亲密，这时却要显露你的骄横气概，发挥你的勇武威势，就一定难逃法网了。因此称得上圣人的人，能阴能阳，能弱能强；随顺时世来行动，凭着自己的天资来立功；事物运动起来知道它的转化，事情有了苗头观察它的动向；变化了能认识它的新模样，运动的有法子对付。因此圣人终生顺利而没有困窘。所以事情有的可以做但不能说，有的可以说但不能真地去干，有的容易做但难成功，有的难成功而容易败坏。所谓可以做而不能说的，是取舍；可以说但不能真地去干的，是欺诈；容易做但难成功的，是事业；难成就而容易败坏的是名声。这四种策略，是圣人独到的见识并且注意的事。

从前曹沫为鲁国带兵作战，三战三不胜，丢失土地千里。假若当时曹子心中不考虑将来长远之计，不转身朝后逃，在阵前圳颈自杀，那么他永远是个败军的败将了。可是曹子不为一时的失败而害羞，他感到羞耻的是不能建功立业。后来在柯地齐、鲁会盟时，他拔出三尺利剑，比着齐桓公的胸膛，逼迫齐桓公归还夺走的土地，三次战争中丧失的国土，片刻之间便收回了。他的大勇大智天下闻名，为鲁国立下功勋。管仲辅佐公子纠继承君位不能成功，不能说他聪明；在公子纠与小白争权的战斗中失败自顾逃命，不能为纠的灾难而死＇，不能叫勇敢；在被小白关押后，又接受鲍叔举荐，为桓公效力，不以此为耻辱，不能叫贞节。有了这不智、不勇、不贞三种德行，平民不愿和他交朋友，君王不愿以他为臣。可是管仲从囚禁中解放出来受到桓公重用，执掌齐国政事，九次盟会诸侯，一度扶正周王室。假若管仲当初身临绝境献出生命，不考虑以后的大计，哪有助桓公称霸的功勋呢！如果君王评价他的臣属不考虑臣的大功，不着眼千臣的大节，只要求臣的小节，这便是失去贤才的做法。．所以只要一个人有大德，就不用非议他的小节；如果有大的名誉，就不必吹毛求疵，纠住小的失误。牛蹄踩成的小水曲里长不出蝗鱼和鲜鱼，蜂窝里容不下天鹅蛋，形体狭小的东西包容不了形体大的东西呀。人的常情，没有谁没短处。如果他的大的方面是正确的，虽然有些小过错，也不足以成为累赘。如果他大的方面错了，虽然有受邻里夸赞的品行，也不值得重用。那梁啄聚，曾经是梁父山中的大盗，后来成了齐国忠臣。段干木原先是在晋国作经纪人的，后来魏文侯引以为老师。孟卯娶他嫂子作老婆，生下五个孩子，后来做魏相，替魏国解除危难。景阳沉溺千酒色，常常披头散发，和女人鬼混，后来率领楚军救助燕国，声威慑服诸侯。这四个人，都有短处，可是功名留传后世，因为他们大的才干得到了施展。季哀、陈仲子坚持节操，行为清高，不肯跻身

所以普通的铸剑工匠常常把普通的剑当成了莫邪宝剑，只有欧冶那样的神冶工能识别它们的种类；普通的玉工常常把一般的玉当成碧卢美玉，只有鉴别珠宝的专家椅顿才能不弄错；糊涂昏庸的君王常常把伪装成君子的奸臣小人当成了君子，只有圣明的君王才能从隐微的迹象中看清真相。所以，根据蛇昂头的高低尺度，可以知道它的长短；象的牙长得有多长，可以论定它的年龄大小。薛地的烛庸氏之子，看到爪甲那么长的短剑，就能识别一般剑的利钝；把淄河、涓河的水混放着，臾儿、易牙，只要尝一口便能根据甜苦分出哪是淄河的水，哪是涓河的水。所以圣人识别贤才，看到他的一种行为，贤或不贤就分清了。孔子推辞廪丘办封邑，据此可以断定他绝不至于去偷盗刀钩一类不值钱的小玩艺；许由连天子高位都不肯接受，据此可以断定他绝不稀罕封侯之赏。所以不曾被火烧伤过的人不敢抓住火，是因为他常常看到火是会烧死人的；不曾被刀剑刺伤的人不敢抓住锋刃，是由于他看到过刀剑的锋刃是能伤人的。由此看来，从已经看见的现象可以推知还没有发生的事，观察小节可以推知大体。所以评价人才的方法，地位尊贵时看他怎样举荐别人的，富有时看他施舍的多少，处境困窘时看他不接受什么，地位卑下时看他不做哪些事，贫穷时看他不拿取别人的钱财。观察他经历危难的情形，看他勇气如何；拿他喜爱的东西触动他，看他操守怎样；交给他钱财，判断他是否仁爱；用恐惧的事震动他，看他有无节操：这样多侧面的反复观察考查，令一个人各个方面的情况便了解得全面了。

这就是奖赏少数的人而勉励的人很多。

齐威王在庭院里摆好大鼎，列举无盐县令的罪状说：＂赞颂你政绩的声音，每天通过你收买的人传到我的耳中。但我派人检查了你在无盐干的事，那里田野荒芜，仓廪空虚，监狱里关满了人。你是用奸诈来欺骗我。”千是烹了无盐令。齐国从此以后三十二年路不拾遗。这就是刑罚简省而奸邪禁绝。秦穆公出外游猎，马车破了，居右的服马逃走，被乡下人捉去。穆公带人追到岐山南边，乡下人正杀死那匹马煮着吃。穆公对他们说：＂吃这种骏马的肉，如果不随着喝酒，会伤身子的。我特地赶来是怕伤了你们身体。”说完叫随从人员让乡下人全喝过酒才离开。过一年，秦穆公和晋惠公在韩源交战，晋军包围了穆公的指挥车，晋国大夫梁由靡已经拉住穆公的骏马，正要活捉穆公。去年吃马肉的一伙三百多人，都冒死为保卫穆公在指挥车周围拼杀，终千打败晋军，俘虏了晋惠公胜利归国。这便是费用省约而得到报答多。齐桓公准备出征讨伐诸侯中发动战乱的人，但恺甲兵器不够用，于是发布命令，让犯有重罪的犯人每人出三副恺甲一支戟抵罪，轻罪犯人按罪行轻重程度拿出不同分量的铜铁赎罪，输了官司的人出一束箭。老百姓都很高兴，纷纷选用直箭竹来做箭，熔铸铜铁造出各种兵刃，桓公用这些武器征讨不义之君，无道之国，终千称霸天下。这就是收入多但老百姓没有怨言。所以圣明的君王依照人民的喜好来鼓励人民向善，依照人民憎恶的来禁止奸邪，所以能够奖赏一个人而天下人都赞颂，惩罚一个人而天下人都害怕。所以说最有效的赏赐不费事，最有效的惩罚不毫无节制。孔子杀掉少正卯而鲁国的歪风邪气堵住了，子产杀掉邓析郑国的奸邪禁绝了，这两位政治家都能由近论远，由小知大。所以圣人主张掌握住要领而收广泛的效果，说的就是这个道理。

所谓做坏事，是急躁贪欲多导致的。心情安适，去掉多余的欲念，不受诱惑，依循天性，保住纯真，不让自己发生变异，就能为善，所以说为善容易。而干坏事要翻越城墙，越过险要的关卡，偷盗符节、印章、钥匙，篡位、杀人、制浩假命令、编造谎言，这些胡作非为，都是违反人的天性的，所以说作恶是难事。现在人们之所以犯被关押的罪行或者陷进刑杀的祸患之中，是因为嗜欲无限膨胀，不知节制的缘故。怎么知道是这样呢？天下公布着国法：＂盗墓的处死，偷窃的判刑。”这是当政者主管着的。那法令针对着不法之徒，法网随时搜寻着坏人的踪迹，无论是愚笨的男子还是蠢笨的妇人，都懂得干坏事、触犯刑律是逃脱不了法律制裁的。但是那些不成器的子弟，贪欲无穷无尽，冒着死罪去干坏事，终于遭受刑杀的耻辱。每年立秋以后，司法人员接连不断来到死囚牢门提取犯人，在十字街头处死的罪犯血流满路。为什么会落得这样的下场？因为被谋取不义之财的贪心弄昏了头脑，因而看不到死亡的祸患在等着自己。现在战场上两军对垒，摆开阵势，将官下军令说：＂斩敌首的封给爵位，后退逃跑的腰斩。”但是阵列中的士卒都不能够冲锋前进争取斩敌首立功，却向后溃退受腰斩的惩治，这是只害怕前进会被敌人杀死，却不明白后退必定按军法处死。所以利益会812 淮南子全译向灾害转化，跟着福后头的是祸，这个道理不能不弄明白呀！

18.1 有些事情，

恰恰因此而失去；有时你本来想回避开，恰恰因此而撞个满怀。有个楚国人乘船过江遇上大风，巨浪袭来，此人非常惊恐，为了避开浪头竟自己跳进江里。他不是不贪生怕死，而是给怕死的念头给吓昏了反而忘掉了要活命。所以人的嗜欲，也就像这样。有个齐国人偷金子，正当集市上十分热闹的时候，他去了，抓起金子便跑开。捉住他的人问他：“你敢在集市上偷金子，哪来这么大的胆子？“齐人回答说：＂我没看见人，眼睛里只有金子！“心里装的尽是想要的东西，所以就不顾自己是在干什么了。因此圣人仔细考察事物运动和静止的变化，恰如其分地掌握接受和给予的分寸；理顺爱憎的感情，调和喜怒的情绪使它们有节制。动静得当，祸患就不来光顾；接受给予适度，罪过就不来缠着；爱憎理顺了，忧虑就不沾边；喜怒有节制，怨恨就不来侵犯。所以通达道术的人，不随随便便捞好处，也不推让应得的福利；自己该享
